#Text=2. Related Work
#Text=2.1. Bloom ’s Taxonomy for Construction Hazard Education
#Text=Bloom ’s cognitive taxonomy was an attempt to improve educational objectives regarding assessment and testing of teaching materials .

#Text=It provided an organizational structure including six categories , namely knowledge , comprehension , application , analysis , synthesis and evaluation , which are arranged from the simplest to the most complex .
#Text=Subsequently , many theorists have developed improvements in the domains of human learning such as effective domain and psychomotor domain .
#Text=In 2001 , Anderson and Krathwohl proposed a revised Bloom ’s taxonomy which improved from uni-dimension to two-dimension .
#Text=In the knowledge dimension , the authors classified four types : factual , conceptual , procedural , and metacognitive knowledge .
#Text=In the cognitive process dimension , six levels were changed into verb format : 1-remembering , 2-understanding , 3-applying , 4-analyzing , 5-evaluating , and 6-creating .
#Text=With the combination of two dimensions , educators could change from passive views of learning towards active engagement in meaningful learning .
#Text=Bloom ’s taxonomy and its revised version became the standard for designing educational curricula .
#Text=For example , Thambyah et al. recommended twenty four learning outcomes based on the revised Bloom ’s taxonomy for the final year project of undergraduate engineering .

#Text=In addition , it provided for teachers a common language to compare and discuss between two different subject areas , understand how these subjects overlap , and deliver the conceptual and practical knowledge concurrently .
#Text=Thus , Bloom ’s taxonomy could widely influence the educational systems as a whole , through teacher preparing programs , assessment programs , and educational research .

#Text=A survey of the education literature also revealed that several studies attempted to apply and implement the taxonomy in many domains of education including computing , medical and nursing , music , and engineering .
#Text=In the construction hazard domain , there is a potential to apply Bloom ’s taxonomy for educational enhancement .
#Text=The recent assessment methods reveal a gap in evaluating the implementation level of safety knowledge and skills in practice .

#Text=To overcome these gaps , appropriate approaches and solutions based on cognitive and awareness processes should be proposed to achieve the learning outcomes and maximize the collective amount of knowledge for each objective .
#Text=Using Bloom ’s taxonomy , Kaskutas et al. identified the gap between fall prevention training and the favorite learning methods of apprentices , and then designed new curricula .
#Text=Endroyoa et al. built an occupational safety and health model to achieve learning outcomes according to Bloom ’s taxonomy .
#Text=Pedro et al. proposed a context-based assessment system to improve visualization in teaching safety knowledge .
#Text=Moreover , there is a growing tendency to apply modern technologies to construction hazard education .
#Text=Building anatomy modelling and social virtual reality integrated into construction safety system are some examples .
#Text=Although most studies have their own evaluation system , the application of Bloom ’s taxonomy could be beneficial in helping educational programs better meet their learning objectives .
#Text=2.2. Virtual Reality in Construction Hazard Investigation
#Text=Virtual Reality ( VR ) has been applied widely in the context of hazard education and training in recent years .
#Text=Several VR applications have been developed for hazard identification for targeted users such as designers , site workers , construction students , safety managers , among others .

#Text=For example , these research efforts include Design-for-Safety-Process ( DFSP ) systems , Cave Automatic Virtual Environments ( CAVEs ) , System for Augmented Virtuality Environments ( SAVEs ) , Visualized Safety Management System ( VSMS ) , Multiuser Virtual Safety Training System ( MVSTS ) , among others .

#Text=Le et al. developed a learning framework based on an online social VR system , which includes role-playing , dialogic learning , and social interaction for construction safety and health education .

#Text=Following this , researches have proved the advantages of VR in providing interactive and experiential learning environments , which are very important to motivate and engage learners in obtaining hazard knowledge and skills .

#Text=In an effort to develop VR systems that can provide close-to-reality visibility , recent studies have adopted the 360VP technology , which captures 360 panorama images of real construction sites .

#Text=The 360VP enhances the real-world learning environment by presenting the dynamic nature of construction sites in reality to improve the hazard investigation knowledge skills of construction students and professionals .
#Text=Furthermore , 360VP has demonstrated improvements in not only hazard education and training , but also energy-efficiency .

#Text=Since VR or 360VP have their own limitations , researches have tried to integrate some VR technologies in order to enhance the advantages of these VR technologies so that hazard education and training can be improved .
